skill.name: the-archivist
skill.description: Enforces systematic decision documentation during code implementation. Ensures every engineering choice includes rationale and context, integrating with Architecture Decision Records for long-term knowledge preservation.
skill.summary: Document engineering decisions with Architecture Decision Records during code implementation
skill.author: Cygnusfear

security_audit.summary: All 91 static findings are false positives from markdown documentation examples. The skill contains only documentation templates and guidance for Architecture Decision Records. No executable code, network requests, or file operations beyond standard Claude Code capabilities. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Engineering decisions often lose their rationale over time, causing teams to repeat mistakes or reverse carefully considered choices. The Archivist ensures every technical decision is documented with context, alternatives, and reasoning using Architecture Decision Records.
actual_capabilities: Provides three-tier decision documentation framework from inline comments to full ADRs
Includes ready-to-use templates for Architecture Decision Records and decision logs
Offers decision detection triggers to identify when documentation is needed
Integrates with code review and planning workflows for systematic decision tracking
Supplies enforcement protocols and verification checklists for consistent documentation
limitations: Does not automatically detect or generate decision documentation from existing code
Requires manual discipline to follow documentation practices during implementation
Templates are opinionated and may need customization for specific team workflows
Does not integrate with external decision tracking or project management tools

use_cases.title: Document Architectural Choices
use_cases.description: When implementing a new microservice architecture, use the skill to create full ADRs documenting technology selections, service boundaries, and communication patterns. Future teams will understand why specific patterns were chosen over alternatives.

use_cases.title: Track Technical Trade-offs
use_cases.description: During performance optimization, document decisions about caching strategies, database denormalization, or algorithm choices. The decision log preserves the rationale for trade-offs made between speed, memory, and maintainability.

use_cases.title: Maintain Implementation Context
use_cases.description: While building features, use inline decision comments and brief ADRs to explain why specific libraries were chosen, why certain API designs were preferred, or why code deviates from established patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Create Inline Decision Comment
prompt_templates.prompt: I am choosing to use approach X instead of approach Y. Help me write an inline decision comment explaining why.
prompt_templates.scenario: For local, easily reversible implementation choices

prompt_templates.title: Write Brief ADR Entry
prompt_templates.prompt: I decided to use library X for feature Y. Create a brief decision entry for DECISIONS.md that includes context, rationale, and alternatives rejected.
prompt_templates.scenario: For module-level decisions affecting multiple files

prompt_templates.title: Generate Full ADR
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to document our decision to use technology X for system Y. Create a full ADR covering context, decision drivers, considered options, and consequences.
prompt_templates.scenario: For architectural decisions with system-wide impact

prompt_templates.title: Review for Missing Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my recent code changes and identify any engineering decisions that need documentation. Suggest which tier of documentation each decision requires.
prompt_templates.scenario: During code review or pre-commit checks

output_examples.input: I chose PostgreSQL over MongoDB for our user database
output_examples.output:
Brief ADR entry:

Decision 0012: Use PostgreSQL for User Database
Date: 2026-01-21 | Status: Accepted

Context: Need persistent storage for user accounts with complex relational queries and strong consistency guarantees.

Decision: Use PostgreSQL for primary user database.

Rationale: Provides ACID guarantees, mature tooling, team expertise, excellent JSON support for flexible fields, and handles complex joins for user permissions model.

Alternatives Rejected:
- MongoDB: Eventual consistency issues for user auth, less mature transaction support, weaker query capabilities for relational data
- MySQL: PostgreSQL has better JSON support and more advanced features we will need

Consequences: Requires PostgreSQL infrastructure, slightly higher resource usage than NoSQL, but gains strong consistency and query flexibility.

best_practices: Document decisions before implementing code to force clear thinking and prevent the common pattern of never documenting later
Match documentation depth to decision significance using the three-tier system to avoid both over-documentation and under-documentation
Always include alternatives that were rejected and explain why to help future engineers understand the full context
anti_patterns: Avoid writing ADRs after the fact to justify decisions that were already made without genuine consideration of alternatives
Do not create detailed ADRs for trivial choices like variable names or framework conventions that follow standard patterns
Never modify or delete accepted ADRs when decisions change, instead create new superseding ADRs to preserve historical context

faq.question: When should I write a full ADR versus a brief decision entry?
faq.answer: Use full ADRs for architectural decisions that affect multiple modules, have high reversal cost, or require stakeholder input. Brief entries work for module-level decisions with moderate impact. The skill includes a decision tree to help classify choices.

faq.question: How does this integrate with Claude Code workflows?
faq.answer: The Archivist activates during code implementation when you make technical choices. It provides templates and guidance but requires manual execution. It works alongside planning and code review skills to ensure decisions are documented.

faq.question: Do I need to document every single code decision?
faq.answer: No. Trivial choices like variable names, standard framework patterns, and language idioms do not need formal documentation. Focus on decisions where forgetting the rationale would cause problems or where reasonable alternatives existed.

faq.question: What if our team already has ADR templates?
faq.answer: The templates provided are MADR-inspired and can be customized. The core value is the decision detection triggers and enforcement protocol, which work with any ADR format your team prefers.

faq.question: How do I handle decisions that were made before using this skill?
faq.answer: You can retroactively document important historical decisions, but mark them clearly with the actual decision date and note they are retrospective. Focus on documenting new decisions prospectively for best results.

faq.question: Can this skill automatically detect undocumented decisions in my code?
faq.answer: No, it provides manual checklists and review guidelines. You must actively identify decisions during implementation and code review. The skill offers detection triggers and questions to help identify what needs documentation.
